urn:contentItem:5Y4T-CG41-JDJN-616J-00000-00UAE considers lifting ban on WhatsApp calls2019-11-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:40:08ZLexisNexisUAE considers lifting ban on WhatsApp callsMariam M. Al Serkal, Web Chief Reporter

WhatsApp app on a smartphone. Image Credit: Agency Also in this package

Business community renews call for relaxing of Skype ban
No issue with licensed VoIP services in UAE: TRA
Microsoft confirms talks with UAE's Telecommunications Regulatory Authority to lift Skype ban

Dubai: The UAE may soon remove the ban on WhatsApp voice calls, marking it the first free Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) services to be available in the country.

The Telecommunications Regulatory Authority (TRA) currently restricts the usage of many applications of VoIP in the UAE, such as Skype, Tango, Face time and Viber.

Botim, C'me and YzerChat are the only two VoIP apps authorised in the UAE.

In an interview with CNBC, Mohammad Al Kuwaiti, executive director of the UAE's National Electronic Security Authority, said the UAE had increased its collaborations with big tech platforms on national security initiatives, especially with the Facebook-owned WhatsApp.

"The collaboration with WhatsApp has actually increased, and in many of those [projects] we saw a very good understanding [from them] of the concept we have," he said during the programme "Capital Connection".

"There might be a lift of that ban for [WhatsApp] voice calls… and this is going to happen soon, this is what we know and understand from the telecommunication authority here in the UAE," said Al Kuwaiti.

When contacted by Gulf News on Thursday, the TRA declined to comment.

Earlier this year, Gulf News reported that talks were already in place between officials from Smart Dubai and "strategic partners and the telecommunication industry" to lift the VoIP restrictions in the UAE.

Dr Aisha Bint Butti Bin Bishr, Director General of the Smart Dubai Office, exclusively told Gulf News: "When it comes to telecommunications, we are working very closely with our strategic partners and the telecommunication industry to understand with them how we can lift these kind of restrictions to boost our economy more."

Last year, Microsoft confirmed that it was in talks with the TRA to lift the ban on Skype. Skype is part of Microsoft Office 365 and at present, only the text-based chat feature in Skype is available for businesses.

In December 2017, Etisalat and du blocked Skype throughout the country as the app provided unlicensed VoIP services, "which falls under the classification of prohibited contents as per the United Arab Emirates' Regulatory Framework."

urn:contentItem:5Y4T-CGB1-JDJN-6223-00000-00UAE considers lifting ban on WhatsApp calls2019-11-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:40:08ZLexisNexisUAE considers lifting ban on WhatsApp calls

The UAE may soon remove the ban on WhatsApp voice calls, marking it the first free Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) services to be available in the country.

The Telecommunications Regulatory Authority (TRA) currently restricts the usage of many applications of VoIP in the UAE, such as Skype, Tango, Face time and Viber.

Botim, Cme and YzerChat are the only two VoIP apps authorised in the UAE.

In an interview with CNBC, Mohammad Al Kuwaiti, executive director of the UAEs National Electronic Security Authority, said the UAE had increased its collaborations with big tech platforms on national security initiatives, especially with the Facebook-owned WhatsApp.

The collaboration with WhatsApp has actually increased, and in many of those [projects] we saw a very good understanding [from them] of the concept we have, he said during the programme Capital Connection.

There might be a lift of that ban for [WhatsApp] voice calls and this is going to happen soon, this is what we know and understand from the telecommunication authority here in the UAE, said Al Kuwaiti.

When contacted by Gulf News on Thursday, the TRA declined to comment.

Earlier this year, Gulf News reported that talks were already in place between officials from Smart Dubai and strategic partners and the telecommunication industry to lift the VoIP restrictions in the UAE.

Dr Aisha Bint Butti Bin Bishr, Director General of the Smart Dubai Office, exclusively told Gulf News: When it comes to telecommunications, we are working very closely with our strategic partners and the telecommunication industry to understand with them how we can lift these kind of restrictions to boost our economy more.

Last year, Microsoft confirmed that it was in talks with the TRA to lift the ban on Skype. Skype is part of Microsoft Office 365 and at present, only the text-based chat feature in Skype is available for businesses.

In December 2017, Etisalat and du blocked Skype throughout the country as the app provided unlicensed VoIP services, which falls under the classification of prohibited contents as per the United Arab Emirates' Regulatory Framework. 2019 Global Data Point.

urn:contentItem:5XKD-BXH1-JD34-V186-00000-00Uber boss bullish as cab industry hits back;Exclusive2019-11-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:40:08ZLexisNexisCOMPUTERSPg. 19Uber boss bullish as cab industry hits backExclusivePaul Smith

The new boss of Uber's Australian ride-sharing business says the company will soon expand across Australia, with New South Wales completed next year, in the face of heightened competition from a resurgent taxi industry that believes it has caught up with better services on its own apps.

Uber this month promoted Dom Taylor, a former investment banker at Morgan Stanley and Macquarie Group, to run the Australia and New Zealand business.

He said Uber already has 80,000 drivers active across Australia and New Zealand and that it viewed customers' attachment to their second cars as a bigger competitor than emerging ride-sharing rivals such as Ola, Shebah, Taxify and traditional taxi-based services such as 13cabs.

However, the major taxi operator, ASX-listed A2B Australia, said it had recovered from the black eye Uber inflicted when it launched and had updated its own technology and customer service to an extent that Uber defectors are returning in droves.

A2B is the parent company of 13cabs, Mobile Technologies International, Silver Service, Cabcharge Payments, and EFT Solutions. Chief executive Andrew Skelton said new features, not available on Uber, make it better for riders and more commercially viable for drivers.

In addition to a new Jetstar-style cut-price taxi brand called Champ, unveiled to investors last week, Mr Skelton said 13cabs would launch a service called MyDriver nationwide after a successful trial in Newcastle.

MyDriver allows 13cabs passengers to create in the app a bank of drivers they trust, so they can book them again. Alternatively,passengers can exclude or block a driver from future bookings.

In trials, Mr Skelton said 40 per cent of passengers chose to select a preferred driver.

"It doesn't work for the ride-share apps to have a direct relationship between driver and passenger, because they have to be clipping the ticket along the way," he said.

"Its good for customers who get to trust drivers and it means drivers are directly rewarded for providing great service, so they can build up their own book of clients, which we hope, one day, that they can monetise."

The perspectives of Mr Taylor and Mr Skelton could not be more different on the issue of competition and impact on society of the growth of Uber.

Mr Taylor said that although the market had become more competitive in the past couple of years, he felt Uber's reach and number of drivers meant it would remain first choice for most customers.

"The reality is that we have been here in Australia since 2012. We were the pioneers of the ride-share market in Australia. That means that we've got a scale of operations that no other competitor has across Australia, and with scale comes benefits that we can flow back to consumers," he said.

"We have also built trusting relationships [with customers] and worked with governments to establish ride-share regulations."

Mr Skelton, however, is scathing of the manner in which Uber has established its market share and believes customers, as well as drivers, have been willing the taxi industry to lift its game so they can return.

"We had an app before Uber existed that we built in-house. It's just we made the mistake, silly us, of deploying it through the legal framework, whereas they came in and just barrelled over all the local regulators," he said.

Whereas Mr Skelton has been publicly critical of Uber's role in adding to congestion on the roads, Mr Taylor says Uber's software is helping to take the strain off infrastructure by making cities work better. He also defends Uber's contribution to the economy by providing flexible employment.

However, as with a number of big tech companies, the apparent value earned by Uber's services in Australia is far removed from the taxes paid locally. In its 2018 local financial numbers lodged with the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, Uber reported a gross profit of $785 million but paid just $8.5 million in company tax. Its accounts say most of the local profits were wiped out by a $691 million "service fees" charge, which it paid to another, unspecified part of the company overseas.

Mr Taylor said it had to pay the global organisation for development of its apps and services. "The company is losing billions of dollars because it is investing in growth," he said.

"It is pretty basic accounting of transfer pricing, but each country has to pay their part of the global overhead that they were accountable for using ... we don't have engineers and tech resources in Australia.
